clean_story:
"Hidden filters. Opinions shaped by unseen forces. "

Bias is like wearing tinted glasses—you see the world, but colors shift without you noticing.
It’s not about lying; it’s about the brain taking shortcuts.
Imagine two people watching the same basketball game.
One cheers for the red team, the other for blue.
Same plays, same ref calls—but each sees fouls differently.
Studies show: when shown identical resumes, hiring managers favor names from their own ethnic group 50% more often.
Even facts get twisted.
A 2018 MIT study found false news spreads 6x faster than truth—because it plays on emotional biases.
Your opinions aren’t just yours.
They’re molded by upbringing, social circles, even the algorithms picking your news.
Ever notice how search results change after one click?
That’s bias in action—quietly narrowing what you see.
The fix isn’t perfection.
It’s pausing to ask: "What might I be missing?"

Echo chambers.
The backfire effect.
How language frames debates.
